title:
An alternative and united proof of a double inequality for bounding the
  arithmetic-geometric mean

title_detail.value:
An alternative and united proof of a double inequality for bounding the
  arithmetic-geometric mean

summary:
In the paper, we provide an alternative and united proof of a double
inequality for bounding the arithmetic-geometric mean.

summary_detail.value:
In the paper, we provide an alternative and united proof of a double
inequality for bounding the arithmetic-geometric mean.

author: Anthony Sofo
journal_reference:
University Politehnica of Bucharest Scientific Bulletin Series
  A---Applied Mathematics and Physics 71 (2009), no. 3, 69--76
fulltext:
arXiv:0902.2515v1 [math.CA] 15 Feb 2009

AN ALTERNATIVE AND UNITED PROOF OF A DOUBLE
INEQUALITY FOR BOUNDING THE
ARITHMETIC-GEOMETRIC MEAN
FENG QI AND ANTHONY SOFO
Abstract. In the paper, we provide an alternative and united proof of a
double inequality for bounding the arithmetic-geometric mean.

1. Introduction
The complete elliptic integral of the first kind was defined as

Key words and phrases. alternative and united proof, double inequality, arithmetic-geometric
mean, complete elliptic integral of the first kind, generalized logarithmic mean.
The first author was partially supported by the China Scholarship Council.

F. QI AND A. SOFO

It is known that a generalization of the logarithmic mean L(a, b) is the generalized
logarithmic mean L(p; a, b) of order p ∈ R, which may be defined [5, p. 385] by


p=0
for positive numbers a and b with a 6= b, and that L(p; a, b) is strictly increasing
with respect to p ∈ R. Therefore, one may naturally pose the following problem.

Problem 1. What are the best constants 0 ≥ β > α ≥ −1 such that the double
inequality
L(α; a, b) < M (a, b) < L(β; a, b)
(10)
holds for all positive numbers a and b with a 6= b? In other words, are the constants
α = −1 and β = 0 the best possible in the inequality (10)?
It is easy to see that the complete elliptic integral K(a, b) of the first kind tends
to infinity as the ratio ab for a > b > 0 tends to zero, equivalently, the arithmeticgeometric mean M (a, b) tends to zero as ab → 0+ . As ab → 0+ , the logarithmic
mean L(a, b) also tends to 0. However, the exponential mean I(a, b) does not tend
to zero as ab → 0+ . These phenomenons motivate us to put forward an alternative
problem as follows.
Problem 2. What are the best constants β > α ≥ 1 such that the double inequality
αL(a, b) < M (a, b) < βL(a, b)

(11)

holds for all positive numbers a and b with a 6= b?
In [15] and [16, Theorem 1.3], among others, the right-hand side inequality in (11)
was verified to be valid for β = π2 .
The aim of this paper is to confirm and sharpen the inequality (11) alternatively
and unitedly.
Our main result may be recited as the following theorem.
Theorem 1. The double inequality (11) is valid for all positive numbers a and b
with a 6= b if and only if α ≤ 1 and β ≥ π2 .
Remark 1. Some inequalities were established in [3, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 18] for
bounding the complete elliptic integrals.
2. Lemmas
For proving our theorem alternatively and unitedly, we will employ the following
lemmas.

(32)

It is easy to see that the inequality (32) is valid for all positive numbers a and b
with a 6= b. This implies that the double inequality (11) is valid for all positive
numbers a and b with a 6= b if and only if α ≤ π2 and β ≥ 1. The proof of Theorem 1
is complete.

 A DOUBLE INEQUALITY FOR THE ARITHMETIC-GEOMETRIC MEAN

Acknowledgements. The authors appreciate Associate Professor Chao-Ping Chen
in China for his recommending the reference [4] and some valuable comments in
an e-mail to the first author on 8 June 2008. This paper was completed while
the first author was visiting the Research Group in Mathematical Inequalities and
Applications, Victoria University, Melbourne, Australia between March 2008 and
February 2009 by the grant from the China Scholarship Council. So the first author
expresses many thanks to the local colleagues such as Professors Pietro Cerone and
Sever S. Dragomir for their invitation and hospitality throughout this period.
